title: Revolut Launches Crypto Trading Platform ‘Revolut X’ for UK Retail Customers
content: Global fintech firm Revolut has introduced its standalone crypto trading platformÂ called RevolutÂ X, catering toÂ UKÂ retail customers.Â
The company, whichÂ initiallyÂ began operations in theÂ UKÂ in 2015 offering money transfers, expanded its services to include cryptocurrency buying, holding, and exchanging in 2017.Â
With over 40 million customers worldwide, Revolut has emerged as the largest fintech company in theÂ UK.
AccordingÂ to a statement, Revolut designed the new platform to compete with leading crypto exchanges by providing easy on/off-ramping and low fees.Â
Although initially targeted at professional traders, Revolut X is accessible on desktop for allÂ UKÂ users with a Revolut retail accountÂ starting today.
Traders on Revolut X can engage in more than 100 token trades with fixed fees of 0% for makers and 0.09% for takers, irrespective of trading volume.Â

While the platform will initially offer the same assetsÂ availableÂ on the Revolut retail app, such as bitcoin, ether, and XRP, Revolut plans to expand the selection in the upcoming months, as confirmed by a company spokesperson.

The firm also allows users to trade between fiat and crypto, without any limits or fees, between Revolut X and Revolut.

“We are excited by the introduction of our new crypto product, and believe this top-tier trading platform will change the game for experienced crypto traders, providing them with a safe and accessible place to trade,” Leonid Bashlykov, Revolut’s Head of Crypto Exchange Product, said.
“We understand that competitive feesÂ as well asÂ easy on and off-ramping are at the heart of what experienced traders want from a crypto platform.”

Revolut’s introduction of Revolut X followsÂ the launch of Revolut Ramp in March, which enablesÂ users to purchase crypto directly in their Web3 wallets through a partnership with MetaMask developer Consensys.

The rollout of Revolut X signifies the company’s renewed focus on crypto services after suspending crypto trading for itsÂ UKÂ business clients and terminating crypto services in the United States due to a challenging regulatory environment.
In December, Revolut announced the suspension of crypto trading for itsÂ UKÂ business customers, citing the need to adapt to new requirements set by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) in October.Â
The FCA’s crypto advertising rules, including a cooling-off period for first-time investors, aimed to enhance transparency and accuracy inÂ theÂ marketingÂ ofÂ crypto products.Â
However, several firms, including PayPal, encountered difficulties complying with these regulations.
Additionally, in August, Revolut halted its crypto services in the United States, citing regulatory uncertainties and challenges.Â

The decision followed the delisting ofÂ certainÂ tokens, including Polygon (MATIC), Solana (SOL), and Cardano (ADA), which theÂ U.S.Â Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) alleged to be unregistered securities.Â
